fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We proceed by using the universal property for anodyne morphisms. Consider A' \subseteq A_{\text {right}}, the class of morphisms f such that the corresponding h \in A_{\text {inner}} for all g \in M. We need to prove A' is weakly saturated and contains all the relevant horn inclusions. To do this, we fix f to be a particular horn inclusion, and let M' \subseteq M be the class of morphisms g such that the corresponding h \in A_{\text {inner}}. Repeating the argument, we need to show M' is weakly saturated and contains all the boundary inclusions \partial \Delta ^n \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n. This finally reduces the case to a concrete h, given by \Lambda ^{n+m+1}_j \hookrightarrow \Delta ^{n+m+1}. Since we started with f right anodyne, we will end up with 0 < j \le n < n+m+1, so h is obviously inner anodyne. The other claims are similarly reduced to making sure j falls in the right range.

Let M be the class of momomorphisms of augmented simplicial sets. We can define F_{\text {kan/left/right/inner}}, the class of augmented fibrations in the same way as ordinary simplicial sets. Note that we still require n \ge 1 in the horns \Lambda ^n_i. Let A_\bullet be the corresponding class of augmented anodyne maps.

Given two monomorphism f : A_0 \hookrightarrow A and g : B_0 \hookrightarrow B of (augmented) simplicial sets, we consider the inclusion h : (A_0 \star B) \sqcup _{(A_0 \star B_0)} (A \star B_0) \to A \star B. We have the following table of implications: \begin {array}{ccc} f \in A_{\text {right}} & \implies & h \in A_{\text {inner}} \\ f \in A_{\text {left}} & \implies & h \in A_{\text {left}} \\ g \in A_{\text {left}} & \implies & h \in A_{\text {inner}} \\ g \in A_{\text {right}} & \implies & h \in A_{\text {right}} \\ \end {array}

We proceed by using the universal property for anodyne morphisms. Consider A' \subseteq A_{\text {right}}, the class of morphisms f such that the corresponding h \in A_{\text {inner}} for all g \in M. We need to prove A' is weakly saturated and contains all the relevant horn inclusions. To do this, we fix f to be a particular horn inclusion, and let M' \subseteq M be the class of morphisms g such that the corresponding h \in A_{\text {inner}}. Repeating the argument, we need to show M' is weakly saturated and contains all the boundary inclusions \partial \Delta ^n \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n. This finally reduces the case to a concrete h, given by \Lambda ^{n+m+1}_j \hookrightarrow \Delta ^{n+m+1}. Since we started with f right anodyne, we will end up with 0 < j \le n < n+m+1, so h is obviously inner anodyne. The other claims are similarly reduced to making sure j falls in the right range.
